title: Anya Academica
text:
Needs
Anya wants workshops (so that she can allocate focused time) and case studies (for her research). She would like ready-to-use lesson material she could remix for her students and some orientation material to demystify jargon (what the hell is a "pull request"?). Finally, it's important that she be able to use the same tools in her research as in her teaching in order to amortize learning costs and stay in practice.

title: Erika Sanitaria
text:
Erika is a public health professional working at the Ministry of Health in Kenya for almost 2 years. She is looking forward to learning how to Explore data and Make rigorous conclusions from modelling and statistical inference outputs.
Erika is competent in epidemiological concepts given her medical studies and field experience. She took the FETP (Field Epidemiology Training Program) under the TEPHINET (Training Programs in Epidemiology and Public Health Interventions Network)
Erika wants to learn how to wrangle data and create visualisations useful for Situational Reports (sitreps). She also wants to learn how to interpret the outputs of stats and maths modelling generated by specialised R packages to inform stakeholders and the general public.
Erika can read English well, but sometimes struggles to keep up with spoken conversation that involves a lot of jargon. She needs English subtitles in video tutorials.

title: Erika Sanitaria
text:
Needs
Erika wants where to look for stats/maths refreshers. She also wants mid-term mentoring, case-studies per disease type.

title: Epiverse-TRACE personas
text:
Personas help instructors figure out who they’re trying to help and communicate an understanding to each other and to learners. Each persona has a general background, relevant prior knowledge or experience, the learner’s perception of their needs, and any special considerations.

A novice is someone who doesn’t yet have a mental model of some field: as a result, they don’t know what they don’t know. Someone is competent if they know enough to perform routine tasks without heroic effort. Someone is an expert if they are able to solve common problems at a glance and harder or more unusual problems reliably.
Any learning material (lesson, case study, online training, or in-person workshop) should be designed for 1–3 specific personas. The personas above have been synthesized from ones created by Epiverse-TRACE staff, adapting content from Rstudio Learner Personas. Improvements and additions very welcome, and can be made through the GitHub repository.

title: Juan Datero
text:
Juan is a data-savvy professional working at the Ministry of Health in Kenya for almost 2 years. He is looking forward to learning how to carefully use R packages to generate modelling and statistical inference outputs.
Juan is a novice in epidemiological concepts given his engineering and statistics studies. He just started a Online courses in Epidemiology where he is having training in Epidemiology concepts.
Juan wants to learn how to choose the parameters of specialised R packages in a pragmatic way during health emergencies (outbreaks), without losing scientific rigour. Also, he wants to learn how to interpret the outputs of stats and maths modelling generated by these specialised R packages to inform Field epidemiologists. If possible, learn how to contribute to these R packages.
Juan believes that time is money: every minute she spends learning something new has to pay off sooner rather than later.

title: Juan Datero
text:
Needs
Juan wants where to look for outbreak concept refreshers constantly. He also wants case studies and vignettes for his day-to-day work, webinars to give him a sense of where the field is going, and short, intensive online training for very specific.

title: Lucia Outbreaks
text:
Needs
Lucia wants applied statistics and mathematics refreshers. She also wants clear guidelines for the interpretation of Outbreak analytics package outputs.

title: Patricia Discoverer
text: Patricia is a PhD student learning to do exploratory data analysis with R. She works with code at least half of her time, mainly using R for data cleaning and visualization. She is familiar with the Rstudio Graphical Interface.

title: Patricia Discoverer
text:
Needs
Patricia wants to translate theory to practice with R. She wants workshops (as an opportunity to meet people) and self-paced lessons (so that she can learn new things on her own). She has a complete set of cheatsheets taped up on her wall, but usually checks Stack Overflow before looking at reference manuals.

title: Yanni Githuber
text:
Yanni is a health professional working as a researcher in epidemiology with high interest in quantitative and qualitative methods. She works with a team of data analysts (quantitative scientists and engineers). She is looking forward to learning how to work in Open Science projects, and also how to contribute to them.
Yanni is learning how to do exploratory data analysis with R. She works with code at least half of her time, particularly using R for data cleaning and visualisation.
Yanni wants to learn how to access and contribute to code projects that already work with Git as a version control system. She also wants to learn to start a new project on her own, and include better coding practices as soon as possible.
Yanni is not familiar with the terminal window. She never used commands to perform a particular task on her computer.
